Much of Princess Diana's appeal was how she sang off a different hymn sheet to the rest of the House of Windsor. 
She chose her own engagement ring , wrote her own vows, was a hands-on mum and had a tricky love-hate relationship with the press. 
In 1995, she famously declared, "I don't go by a rule book, because I lead from the heart, not the head, and albeit that's got me into trouble in my work." 
Two years later, the woman known as the 'people's princess' was dead at just 36 years old. 
Now, in the new exhibit Diana: Her Fashion Story , 25 of Diana's most iconic outfits will be exhibited along with the stories behind those fashion choices. Diana, Princess of Wales with her sons, Prince William and Prince Harry, at the piano in Kensington Palace (Photo: Getty) 
Diana's use of clothes and accessories also played their own part in her earning the 'people's princess' alias. 
An example of this was her eventually refusing to wear gloves . 
Eleri Lyn, the curator of the exhibit told PEOPLE magazine how, through her official work, Diana wanted to "convey approachability and warmth. Princess Diana (1961 - 1997) shakes hands with singer Mick Hucknall of Simply Red at a rock concert for World AIDS Day at Wembley (Photo: Getty) 
"She abandoned the royal protocol of wearing gloves because she liked to hold hands when visiting people or shake hands and have direct contact." 
Hats also eventually fell by the wayside, "because she said, 'You can’t cuddle a child in a hat." 
It wasn't just accessories she stopped wearing which she used to engage and form a rapport with people. Read More You'll never see the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge holding hands in public - here's why Princess Diana stopped wearing hats and started wearing chunky, bright pieces of jewellery for kids to enjoy (Photo: Tim Graham/Getty Images) 
Eleri continues: "When she was visiting hospitals for example she would wear cheerful clothes that would convey warmth and often chunky jewelry so that children could come and play with them." 
Her style was her way of saying that she cared, and it did not go unnoticed. 
Eleri says Diana's sense of style was intricately linked to her passion for charity work and her desire to help. Read More Why the Queen once hid behind a royal bush – and who she was hiding from Princess Diana Shaking Hands With One Of The Residents Of Casey House (Photo: Getty) 
"She had a great design eye and a real knack for fashion. Although she wanted to focus on her work, she wanted to use fashion to help that." Like us on Facebook
